Code: P104

Method of Study: Full-time
Duration: 3 years (6 semesters)
Starting Months: September
Domestic Tuition: $5,401.00
International Tuition: $18,810.00
Centre: Arts, Design & Information Technology
School: Media & Performing Arts

Fall 2023 Delivery: Semester 1, 3, 5 - On Campus
Winter 2024 Delivery: Semester 2, 4, 6 - On Campus
Program Description: Vigorously concentrated, career-oriented training in the fundamental skills and practicalities needed to work as a professional actor in theatre, television and film.
Location of Training: Young Centre for the Performing Arts, Toronto's Distillery District.
Disclaimer: Expectations of professionalism, group work, intimacy between actors, whispering, consensual touching, combat training, expressions of physicality, deep exploration of self, personal psychological examination, conflict, and successful failure.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Theatre Arts – Performance Program P104 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context: The George Brown College School of Media and Performing Arts offers a Performance program that provides intensive, career-oriented training in acting for theatre, television, and film. The conservatory-style curriculum covers voice, speech, movement, music and dance, improvisation, text analysis, scene studies, clowning, commedia dell’arte, and television and film technique, among other subjects. Students have the opportunity to participate in partnerships with Soulpepper Theatre Company, Tarragon Theatre, and Theatre by the Bay. In their final year, students are paired with a successful theatre practitioner for a mentorship program that continues for approximately a year after graduation. The competitive field of acting has a consistent demand for new talent, and George Brown College is recognized by ACTRA and UDA as an accredited training institution. Graduates can apply to join ACTRA as Apprentice members within one year, and may acquire 15 of the 30 credits required to become an active UDA member under certain conditions. The Performance program offers required courses in the first semester.

Context:
The text provides information about the courses required for different semesters in a theatre program at the college. Here's the key factual information extracted from the text:

- There are four courses in Semester 4: THEA 3014 (Introduction to Alexander Technique), THEA 3017 (Monologue Study), THEA 3018 (The Artist as Producer), and THEA 3019 (Auditioning I).
- There are seven courses in Semester 5: THEA 2025 (Business of Acting II), THEA 3010 (Showcase Performance II), THEA 3013 (Movement VI), THEA 3015 (Introduction to Alexander Technique II), THEA 3020 (Auditioning II), THEA 3015 (Playwriting II), and THEA 3032 (Playwriting II).
- Students may be required to take COMM 1000 (Introduction to College Communication) before progressing to COMM 2000. This course does not count as a course required for graduation, and students will be charged for it.
- The graduate is expected to demonstrate various abilities related to performing in a variety of theatrical contexts, developing personal and professional strategies, analyzing theatre traditions and trends, investigating reasons for pursuing creative work, completing work compliant with industry standards, using entrepreneurial skills for production and administration, and performing vocal material and executing staging and choreography.
- The tuition fees for Domestic students is $5,401.00 and for International students is $18,810.00 per semester. There are additional costs mentioned but no details were provided in the text.

Selection Process: Enrolment is limited and admission is competitive based on the results of auditions and personal interviews.

Course Exemptions: College or university credits may qualify for course exemptions.

Context:
* The text is about applying for the Theatre Arts – Performance program at George Brown College.
* Course exemptions can be obtained with college or university credits. More information can be found on the Transfer Guide.
* International students should refer to the International Admissions page for country-specific admission requirements.
* Applicants for the Theatre Arts – Performance program are required to present two contrasting monologues and one song as part of their application.
  - The first monologue must be from the classical repertoire (before 1700).
  - The second monologue must be contemporary (after 1900).
  - Both monologues must be from published plays, not stories, poetry, movies, TV or self-written material.
  - Monologues should not exceed one and a half minutes each.
  - Applicants should present two contrasting monologues to show different aspects of their personality.
* The song can be from any repertoire. Applicants will sing without accompaniment.
* Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges, while international students should apply through the George Brown College Online Application System.
* Contact information for the School of Media and Performing Arts: phone - 416-415-5000, ext. 2167, email – performingarts@georgebrown.ca.
* For more general information about George Brown College, contact the college's Contact Centre at 416-415-2000 (TTY 1-877-515-5559) or long distance 1-800-265-2002.
* International students can also contact one of the college's international recruitment representatives by booking a virtual meeting or submitting an inquiry through the International Contact Us page.
* The Theatre Arts – Performance program is located at the Young Centre for Performing Arts in Toronto's Distillery District. Campus tours are offered regularly, and a virtual tour is also available.
* Related programs include Acting for Media (P107), Graphic Design (G102), and Video Design & Production (P112).
* The text states that George Brown College offers the best classical theatre training program in Canada.

Context: George Brown Theatre School offers a highly demanding and challenging advanced diploma program in classical theatre. The program provides students with the most current and practical training using the best facilities, guest artists, and faculty. Notable figures associated with the school include George Bernard Shaw and Judith Thompson. Alumni of the program feel prepared to enter the industry as trained professionals upon graduation.
